title: Bump the version to `0.27.0`
body:
The new release brings better test coverage, fixes some issues found during testing, improves performance, and adds new breaking changes.

## Improvements

* fix: Encode SMT error keys by @bvrooman in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/356
* Spec compliance testing, round 1 by @Dentosal in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/345
* Iterate through instruction encondings using codegen by @Dentosal in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/340

## Breaking

* Refactor of `fuel-crypto` for clarity around safety by @mitchmindtree in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/346 - It removes some public functions from `fuel-crypto` primitives that may cause compilation errors.
* Read contract directly into memory by @freesig in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/342 - Adds new traits `StorageSize`, `StorageRead`, `StorageWrite` into `fuel-storage`. The `fuel-vm` requires `InterpreterStorage` to implement those traits now, which can cause compilation errors.

## Fixes
* Fix panics in fuel-vm for exponent or bitshift larger than u32::MAX by @Dentosal in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/344
* Do not allow setting reserved flags by @Dentosal in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/363


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/compare/v0.26.1...v0.27.0

title: Do not allow setting reserved flags
body:
Implementation of https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-specs/pull/457

This is technically a breaking change, but it's unlikely that anyone was relying on this behavior.

title: fix: Encode SMT error keys
body:
Related issues:
- https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/issues/527

When traversing a Merkle tree (during SMT update or delete, during BMT root calculation, etc.) we must access the left or right child of each node along the path. Accessing children is liable to cause a `ChildError` (e.g., `ChildNotFound`, `NodeIsLeaf`), and we must be able to report the key of the invalid child. Currently this is not possible for all keys because some key types, like `[u8; 32]` cannot be used in the error message.

This PR adds a wrapper for a key type that can be used in the `ChildError` error message called `ChildErrorKey`. `ChildErrorKey` implements different display strategies depending on the type of key. Specifically:
- A key of type `[u8; 8]` is displayed as a `u64` (big endian)
- A key of type `[u8; 32]` is displayed as a hex encoded string of the key value

This allows fuel-core to use fallible SMT functions, like `update`, and to generate an error object with the expected key when an error happens.

title: Allow backwards jumps in the predicates
body:
Before release [v0.26.1](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/releases/tag/v0.26.1):

*do not merge*

Master branch now contains breaking changes we don't want to include into fuel-core 0.17.x. This branch is a hotfix patch release that is fixing the behavior of predicates to allow backwards jumps. This PR is just serving as a means of recording this change and to verify CI passes.


After release we create a release [v0.26.1](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/releases/tag/v0.26.1) based on this branch:

Now we can and need to merge it into the master because the release `0.26.1` contains this change.

title: Refactor of `fuel-crypto` for clarity around safety
body:
This started with the aim of carrying over https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-crypto/pull/36 which aimed to address https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-crypto/issues/35, though after noticing a few other instances of the same issue decided to take a closer look throughout the crate.

This PR removes many of the unsafe constructors exposed in the `fuel-crypto` API, some due to the implementations not actually being `unsafe`, and some due to a revised implementation that safely encapsulates the unsafe behaviour.

The `Message` and `Signature` `from_bytes` and `from_bytes_ref` constructors have been documented to clarify expectations that they expect signature or cryptographically hashed data respectively.

The `PublicKey` and `SecretKey` `from_bytes_unchecked` constructors have been made private in order to ensure holding an instance of one of these types guarantees their inner byte arrays at least satisfies the curve.

The original, custom curve-checking functions have been removed in favour of using the secp256k1 library constructors directly which share the same implementation but with an added range check that is likely to get optimised out due to the use of const-sized arrays anyway.

Adds some missing `#[repr(transparent)]` decorators to `fuel-types`.

The `FuelMnemonic` type provided unnecessary indirection between the user and the free function, and has been removed in favour of exposing the function directly from the crate root.

title: Spec compliance testing, round 1
body:
Steps towards verifying some fundamental spec compliance features, namely:

* Opcodes increment $pc by one
* Immediate operands are zero-extended correctly
* ALU operations set $err and $of registers correctly
* Reserved registers cannot be written to

Builds on top of #340 and #344

title: Fix panics in fuel-vm for exponent or bitshift larger than u32::MAX
body: Discovered when writing spec-compliance test suite. This PR doesn't contain test cases for these bugs. Those will be done in a follow-up PR, containing the whole test suite.

title: Read contract directly into memory
body:
This adds a few traits:
- `StorageSize` Allows checking the size of a value without copying or de-serializing into memory
- `StorageRead` Like `io::Read` except takes a key. Not this deals with raw bytes and avoids any de-serialization.
- `StorageWrite` Like `io::Write` except takes a key. Not this deals with raw bytes and avoids any serialization.

This allows cheap copying of contract data directly from storage into the vm memory.
This PR replaces #272

title: Iterate through instruction encondings using codegen
body: Pulls in `strum` dependency to generate enum variant iterators automatically

title: bump 0.25.3
body:
## What's Changed
* Use the recently stabilized checked_ilog by @Dentosal in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/332
* Added additional methods for storage for the cases when the developer need to work with `StorageAsRef` and `StorageAsMut` by @xgreenx in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/331
* Implement `fmt::Display` for `TxPointer` by @mitchmindtree in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/334
* Updated `publish-crates` by @xgreenx in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/333
* Remove `Clone` constraint from `PathIterator` by @bvrooman in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/336


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/compare/v0.25.2...v0.25.3

title: Remove `Clone` constraint from `PathIterator`
body:
Related issues:
- https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/issues/527

Removes `Clone` constraint from `PathIterator` by using `take` instead of `clone`. Requiring `Clone` is too cumbersome because it requires that the `ParentNode::Error` (e.g., `StorageError` in the case of `fuel-core`) also implement `Clone`, which cannot be guaranteed.

title: Implement `fmt::Display` for `TxPointer`
body: Tiny PR that provides a display implementation using the `LowerHex` representation, following suit with the `fuel-types` `Display` implementations. Came across the desire for this while working on the new `forc-tx` command.

title: Use the recently stabilized checked_ilog
body:
Replaces our custom (although stdlib-inspired) solution with a call to the now-stable function in the stdlib.

This PR also upgrades CI Rust version to 1.67 which stabilized this function. This in turn requires some minor changes to appease clippy.

title: Added additional methods for storage for the cases when the developer need to work with `StorageAsRef` and `StorageAsMut`
bump 0.25.2
body: includes fixes for GTF mapping codes

title: Fix GTF Constants to match fuel-spec
body: Corrects issue #297 to ensure VM matches the [spec](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-specs/blob/master/src/vm/instruction_set.md#gtf-get-transaction-fields) for GTF

title: chore: BMT clean up
body:
Changes:
- Remove mut requirement from in memory BMT `root`
- Remove `MerkleTreeError` wrapper around BMT `push` StorageError in return type

title: Some improvements of API after integration of previous release into `fuel-core`
body:
After https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/pull/917 I realized that it would be nice to have some additional methods.

- Added static `empty_root` method to all Merkle trees.
- Added new constructors for double storage key.

title: feat: Separate SMT impls for mutable and immutable storage
body: Similar to https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-merkle/pull/141, this PR separates the SMT implementation blocks across mutable and immutable storage. In some cases, we need to be able to call methods, such as `root` when the tree only has immutable storage access. When a method does not need mutable storage access, these methods can now be called.

title: Remove lifetime from the `Mappable::Key`
body:
## Overview

This PR is a continuation of the https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/301. 
Using the lifetimes in the trait or associated types of `Mappable` added complexity several times that forced the change like [this](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/blob/5727a2e7aa5ac0522d7ebd7a6bfd2df5b90e41d8/fuel-vm/src/interpreter/diff/storage.rs#L75) or [this](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/318/commits/a47439f06afb12c18cac6e38938faa1fdeef21bd). Those changes could be done differently, but still it would still be nice to know the owned type to simplify future development and not look for more complex solutions.

## The change to solve the problem

Renamed `Mappable::GetValue` into `Mappable::OwnedValue`. In the same way, added the `Mappable::OwnedKey` for `Mappable::Key` to know the owned type for key and value. Added `ToOwned` bounds for the `Key` and `Value`, added `From<ToOwned::Owned>` bound for `OwnedKey` and `OwnedValue`:
```rust
    type Key = Self::OwnedKey;
    type OwnedKey = u64;
    type Value = Self::OwnedValue;
    type OwnedValue = Primitive;
```

Now the definition of the `Mappable` connects the `Key` with `OwnedKey` and `Value` with `OwnedValue` and allows easy conversion from reference into owned type.

Adding those bounds doesn't allow conversion between `(&'a ..., &'a ...)` and owned `(..., ...)` tuples. So I removed lifetime `'a` and replaced the tuples with the new double storage key.

Defined two double storage keys for `ContractsAssets` and `ContractsState`.

title: Update default gas costs
body:
After fixing some issues in the benchmarking framework, I reran the suite to correct the cost of `srwq`. The srwq base cost is greatly reduced now.

We will need to update these prices again once SMT merklization is implemented on fuel-core.

title: check if contract already exists before deploying
Make GasCosts serdeable
body: Required by https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/pull/917

title: IntoChecked Predicate Verification
body: Finish todo for making IntoChecked perform full verification including predicates

title: rename Checkable to FormatValidityChecks
body:
Make the intent of checkable more clear that it doesn't cover all potential checks.

I originally set out to extend the checkable trait in the VM to replace the existing full check method with one that also includes predicate execution. However, after some more digging it didn't really make sense to enable predicate verification outside of CheckedTransactions, since predicate verification depends on extra verification not performed by the Checkable trait (such as computing free balances and tracking remaining gas).

Removing Checkable isn't a very clean solution either, since it's used within the impl's of IntoChecked for basic verification.

Ultimately Checkable just means that a transaction has some simple validation procedures that should be performed before attempting to convert into a fully checked transaction type. This is limited to checks that don't compute any sort of dynamic outputs based on input (i.e. remaining gas or free balances) that would be cached as metadata for further execution later on. So this PR scaled back the original ambitions [here](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/307#issuecomment-1386107745) to just adding clarification about what this trait is useful for.

title: Move Checked<Tx> type to the fuel-vm crate
Predicate gas metering
body:
Makes predicates respect gas limit. Currently the transcation gas limit is applied to the predicate as well. Also adds predicates flag to `Checked<Tx>`, and a way to perform that check using `CheckedTxExt` trait in fuel-vm.

The following concerns remain unadressed:

* Should predicates have a separate gas limit and/or gas price factor?
* Should we deduct the gas used by the predicate from the gas available to the transaction?

title: fix missing ret and rvrt costs
Update CI to use custom publisher to support `{ workspace = true }`
body:
I updated [`publish-crates`](https://github.com/xgreenx/publish-crates) to support `{ workspace = true }` syntax.

The main idea is to use `cargo metadata` to parse the manifest instead of manual parsing.

PR into the action: https://github.com/katyo/publish-crates/pull/600

Tested [here](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-dummy-test/actions/runs/3889019903/jobs/6636908278).

title: Add a top-level readme file
body: I realized this repo is missing one, and the repo page looks rather weird without it.

title: Updated `InterpreterStorage` to be object safe
body:
Removed `Sized` from `InterpreterStorage`.
Used GATs for lifetimes in the `Mappable` type to remove `for<'a> StorageInspect<Mappable<'a>>`

title: Fix bug in try_mem_write and try_zeroize
Show and fix bug in try_mem_write
body:
make try_mem_write and try_zeroize testable to show bug in current impl
Now also include the fix

title: Fix features
body:
- Fix compile errors for default crate features.
- Add checks to ci.

title: Return `None` for zeroed `ContractId` in `Receipt`
body:
# Problem

We have optional methods for fetching contract id's from receipts, however the VM returns all zeros instead of None. This caused unexpected failures since downstream we expect these methods to only return Some if there is a real contract id.

# Solution

If contract id is zeroed, convert to an Option::None when fetching receipt fields.

title: Fix bug in `LOGD` which throws `MemoryOverflow` for buffers at the very top of RAM
body:
Closes https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/issues/282

This is quite similar to https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/229

title: state word rwc range
body: Finished implementation of #268

title: Bump version to `0.22.6`
body:
## What's Changed
* Skip empty `Script` transaction by @xgreenx in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/284
* Update LICENSE by @SilentCicero in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-vm/pull/281

## New Contributors

title: Skip empty `Script` transaction
body:
Fixes https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/issues/794

It is fast but not an optimal solution to unblock users. With the right solution, we need to skip execution totally without allocating any memory and `Interpreter`. But it requires some refactoring to support transactions which not affect VM during execution(like empty `Script` or `Create` transactions).

title: `fuel-asm` - refactor for improved type-safety around instructions, opcodes
body:
*This PR is based on the monorepo branch, #274.*

---

This PR includes a pretty significant refactor of the `fuel-asm` crate and updates the `fuel-tx` and `fuel-vm` crates accordingly. The goal is to improve type-safety around the `Instruction` and `Opcode` types, and to derive all items related to the `Instruction` type from a single source of truth: the `impl_instructions!` table.

## Name Changes

The following renames have been performed as a part of this PR to more closely align with [the spec](https://fuellabs.github.io/fuel-specs/master/vm/index.html#semantics):

- `Opcode` -> `Instruction`
- `OpcodeRepr` -> `Opcode`.

The old `Instruction` type has been removed, as it tended to encourage some anti-patterns. Namely, converting to the old `Instruction` type meant we *always* unpacked every possible register ID and immediate value, even if they weren't relevant to the instruction variant specified by the opcode. Further, it allowed access to register IDs and immediates that weren't valid at all to the instruction specified by the opcode.

Instead, the new `Instruction` type requires matching the specific instruction type specified by the opcode before allowing to unpack the valid register IDs and immediate. This also helps to avoid some of the unnecessary unpacking that would occur on every instruction within the `Interpreter::_instruction` step.

Another notable difference is that the new `Instruction` type is *packed* (represented in 4 bytes) while the previous equivalent `Opcode` type was *unpacked* (closer to ~40 bytes). The idea here is that the `Instruction` type should remain in a packed form until the moment it is interpreted, at which point only the relevant data is unpacked based on its opcode variant.

## Handwriting ASM

The process of handwriting ASM has also changed slightly. Previously, handwriting ASM took advantage of the unpacked `Opcode` variant, e.g. `Opcode::ADDI(ra, rb, imm)`. Seeing as the new equivalent `Instruction` enum is packed, we instead provide an `op` module with a convenience function for constructing each type of instruction, e.g. `op::addi(ra, rb, imm)`.

By using a function for constructing handwritten instructions, we can also validate the register ID and immediate arguments to ensure the values specified are within the 6/12/18/24-bit expected range and produce an error otherwise. As these functions are solely for handwriting ASM, which is generally only useful for writing tests or benchmarking, we *panic* in the case that a given register ID or immediate value is out of range. On the other hand, during bytecode decoding, we do *not* check the value range for register IDs or immediates as we know that the values cannot possibly lie outside of the range of valid values when packed within the 32-bit raw instruction layout.

## `impl_instructions!`

The new `impl_instructions!` macro allows us to specify a table of all instructions as a single source of truth, from which the declarations and implementations for `Opcode` and `Instruction` (and the nested instruction variant types) are derived. The idea here is to reduce the need to update multiple areas of the crate each time an instruction is added-to or removed-from the spec, removing some scope for mistakes.

That said, the `macro_rules!` implementation is of course not as easy to read as plain copy-paste branches and types. In order to make it a little more accessible, I've added some detailed docs to the `macros` module which aims to explain how each of the types and implementations are derived. I've also attempted to separate and comment each of the different sets of pattern matching branches within the `macro_rules!` definition to help guide future contributions.

## No Reserved or Undefined Opcodes

The old RESERVED* and Undefined variants have been ommitted from the `Instruction` and `Opcode` types. Instead, we consider encountering these during bytecode decoding as error cases. By making it impossible to construct an `Instruction` or `Opcode` from a reserved or undefined value, we can guarantee that `Instruction` or `Opcode` instances within our code must be valid for a lot more cases.

## Typed `RegId`, `Imm*`

When packing or unpacking instructions from/to their respective register IDs and immediates, we now use unit structs rather than type aliased primitive types. This allows us to guarantee correct masking by construction, and avoids the need to double-check potentially incorrect masks when inspecting the unpacked instruction data.

As a convenience, `Index<RegId>` is implemented for `[T]` where `[T]: Index<usize>`. This makes indexing with the typed `RegId`s into the interpreter's `registers` array more ergonomic and avoids the need to cast to `usize` everywhere.

These types are currently only used for instruction packing/unpacking, though in future PRs we might benefit from further type safety by progressively replacing our use of the old `RegisterId` and `Immediate*` type aliases in favour of the new types.

## Instruction Debug impl

A custom Debug implementation is provided for the new `Instruction` type to make it easier to grok an instruction's contents, e.g.

```rust
println!("{:?}", op::addi(0x10, 0x11, 10));
println!("{:?}", op::sub(0x10, 0x11, 0x12));
```

prints as

```console
ADDI { ra: 16, rb: 17, imm: 10 }
SUB { ra: 16, rb: 17, rc: 18 }
```

which is a bit easier to read than the default implementation which would only show the packed data and look more like this:

```console
ADDI(ADDI([56, 142, 241]))
SUB(SUB([56, 212, 128]))
```

## Removal of `io::{Read/Write}` Implementations

These implementations seemed a little out of place in `fuel-asm`, and noticing that we don't appear to use these downstream, I decided to omit these. Instead, we can always read/write `u32`s or `u8`s and use the provided `Instruction` conversions from there. 

## Breaking !!

As there's quite a bit of breakage throughout these changes, I plan to leave this in draft at least until I've got a follow-up PR ready at the `fuel-core` repo as I imagine there are probably loads of tests, etc there too that will also need updating. I plan to help shepherd these changes up through the SDK and Sway repos too.

## Follow-up

There's still a lot more that can be done to improve type-safety throughout `fuel-vm`. This PR aims to limit the scope of changes to those related to the `Instruction` and `Opcode` types as there's already a lot here. I'll aim to open some follow-up issues I've come across during this refactor and link them back here tomorrow.

title: Update LICENSE
body: Small license nit.

title: Allow vm to take gas costs as input
body:
- Adds the `GasCosts` type.
- Sets the default gas costs.
- Adds `bench-helpers` feature to allow resetting the receipts buffer for benchmarks.
- Adds diffing ability that allows testing any op.
